content:
[DC](/washington-dc)Guide

# DC’s New Restaurant Openings

The latest spots to join the DC food scene.

photo credit: Taqueria Xochi

[Omnia Saed](/contributor/omnia-saed)

If you tried to keep track of every new restaurant and bar in DC, your head might spin. So just read this list instead. These are the openings that seem like they have the most potential. Although, keep in mind, we make no promises about the places we haven’t visited yet. Go forth and be a pioneer—or just keep up with our [Hit List](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-new-washington-dc-restaurants-hit-list) to see which new restaurants we checked out and loved.

###### What Our Ratings Mean

[Learn more](/ratings-explainer)

Unrated: This is a restaurant we want to re-visit before rating, or it’s a coffee shop, bar, or dessert shop. We only rate spots where you can eat a full meal.

## December

[## Springbone Kitchen](/washington-dc/reviews/springbone-kitchen)

[1426 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Springbone%20Kitchen+1426 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007)

$$$$

Springbone Kitchen is a New York-based chain specializing in bone broths. They've also got mushroom broths, and bowls made with grass-fed meats and organic veggies. The Georgetown location is their first outside of the New York area.

[## Juneberry Garage](/washington-dc/reviews/juneberry-garage)

[6810 Cameron Dr NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20012](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Juneberry%20Garage+6810 Cameron Dr NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20012)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Takoma Park](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/takoma-park)

Juneberry Garage started out slinging tacos and cocktails from an Airstream trailer parked on Walter Reed. Now, it's taken over an auto shop on the campus where it serves thin-and-crispy Chicago tavern pizzas, homemade sodas, and other Midwestern snacks in a big indoor-outdoor space overlooking the Great Lawn.

## November

[## Gigi’s Pasta](/washington-dc/reviews/gigis-pasta)

[2000 Washington Pl NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20018](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Gigi%E2%80%99s%20Pasta+2000 Washington Pl NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20018)

$$$$

[Foggy Bottom](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/foggy-bottom)

DC, birthplace of Sweetgreen, loves a customizable bowl. Now, the lunch bowl trend has found its way to Italian food at Gigi's in Western Market. Here, you can build your own pasta bowl. Pick your noodle, sauce, and add proteins like meatballs, roast chicken, and sausage links.

Rey Lopez

[## Atlas Brew Works](/washington-dc/reviews/atlas-brew-works)

[600 Howard Rd SE, Washington, District of Columbia 20020](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Atlas%20Brew%20Works%20+600 Howard Rd SE, Washington, District of Columbia 20020)

$$$$

Anacostia is now home to Atlas Brew Works. This is the brewery's third location, and it's massive. The 24,260 square-foot space has a big taproom, outdoor seating, full brewery operations, and food from Andy’s Pizza. River and skyline views to add to the grandeur of it all.

Atlas Brew Works

[## Taqueria Xochi](/washington-dc/reviews/taqueria-xochi-navy-yard)

[300 Tingey St SE, Washington, District of Columbia 20003](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Taqueria%20Xochi%20+300 Tingey St SE, Washington, District of Columbia 20003)

$$$$

[Navy Yard](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/navy-yard)

Taqueria Xochi, [one of our favorite late night spots](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/taqueria-xochi), just opened a new location in Navy Yard. Unlike at the take-out only U Street location, this one is dine-in, which is great news for everyone who desperately needs a place to eat a quesabirria at 9pm on a Tuesday.

Taqueria Xochi

[1346 T St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Sook+1346 T St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009)

$$$$

[Compass Rose](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/compass-rose) is now Sook, an all-day cafe and wine bar serving breakfast khachapuri loaded with cheese, za’atar, and eggs. You can pair it with specialty drinks like a ginger tamarind espresso tonic or a matcha rose latte, both of which seem specifically engineered to make mornings feel less bleak.

[## Eebee’s Corner Bar](/washington-dc/reviews/eebees-corner-bar)

[1840 Sixth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Eebee%E2%80%99s%20Corner%20Bar+1840 Sixth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Shaw](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/shaw)

Perfect For:[Drinking Great Cocktails](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinking-great-cocktails)[Night On The Town](/washington-dc/perfect-for/night-on-the-town)[Late Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/late-nights)[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)

Another one in Shaw. Eebee’s Corner Bar bills itself as a classic American joint with banana splits, mozzarella sticks, and a reportedly very good burger. Drinks include classics like manhattans, dirty shirleys, and negronis.

Thomas Rose

[## The Harp Cask & Kiln](/washington-dc/reviews/the-harp-cask-and-kiln)

[3126 12th St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20017](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=The%20Harp%20Cask%20%26%20Kiln+3126 12th St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20017)

$$$$

The Harp Cask & Kiln is a modern Irish pub in Brookland. The menu hits all the classics: fish and chips, shepherd’s pie... even a wild ox pie. There’s Guinness on tap (obviously) and a long Irish whiskey list that’s half-off on Wednesdays, which seems like the correct use of Wednesday.

[## Realm Rooftop Bar & Lounge](/washington-dc/reviews/realm-rooftop-bar-and-lounge)

[899 O St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Realm%20Rooftop%20Bar%20%26%20Lounge+899 O St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001)

$$$$

[Bar](/washington-dc/cuisines/bar)

[Shaw](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/shaw)

Shaw has a new bar and lounge with panoramic city views. The menu, led by former Bronze chef Keem Hugley, is largely inspired by the small African country of Seychelles, with tamarind-glazed lamb, oysters, and passionfruit tarts. There are fire pits so we can all pretend winter isn’t real, and a natural wine and DJ night every Tuesday for anyone looking for weeknight plans.

M2 Creatives

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/realm-rooftop-lounge-washington?ref=16825)

[## Isla & Goodlove](/washington-dc/reviews/isla-and-goodlove)

[1100 15th St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20005](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Isla%20%26%20Goodlove+1100 15th St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20005)

$$$$

[Jamaican](/washington-dc/cuisines/jamaican)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

Isla is a Caribbean-inspired spot inside the old [Philotimo](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/philotimo) space. The sprawling dining room is nearly 10,000 square feet, with a cocktail lounge called Goodlove next door. Expect lamb tartare with pickled shrimp, pork chops, chargrilled octopus, crab and cod fritters, and other coastal plates.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/isla-dc)

## October

[## Proper Bar](/washington-dc/reviews/proper-bar)

[300 K St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Proper%20Bar+300 K St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001)

$$$$

[Bar](/washington-dc/cuisines/bar)

[Mt. Vernon Triangle](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/mt-vernon-triangle)

Proper Bar is a new Mount Vernon Triangle spot with a massive 5,000-square-foot space perfect for sipping martinis and pretending you own a townhouse nearby. The kitchen serves up classics like burgers, pasta, and a 32-oz dry-aged tomahawk steak.

SpotHopper

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/proper-bar-washington?ref=16825)

[## Singing Tiger](/washington-dc/reviews/singing-tiger)

[411 New York Ave NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Singing%20Tiger+411 New York Ave NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002)

$$$$

[Fusion](/washington-dc/cuisines/fusion)

[Union Market](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/union-market)

[Union Market](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-dishes-union-market)’s got coffee roasters, oyster bars, and now, karaoke. Inside Hotel Nell, this noodle and karaoke den serves melon nigiri, tonkatsu ramen, and enough sake flights and soju to convince you that your “Stay With Me” cover belongs on TikTok. It doesn’t, but bless your heart for trying.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/singer-tiger-washington?ref=16825)

[## (H)ours At Manifest 002](/washington-dc/reviews/manifest-002)

[1242 Third St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=(H)ours%20At%20Manifest%20002+1242 Third St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002)

$$$$

[Fusion](/washington-dc/cuisines/fusion)

[Union Market](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/union-market)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)[First Dates](/washington-dc/perfect-for/first-dates)[See & Be Seen](/washington-dc/perfect-for/see-and-be-seen)[Drinking Great Cocktails](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinking-great-cocktails)

Manifest 002 isn’t a restaurant so much as a lifestyle center. The Union Market spot has cocktail bars, a cafe-slash-co-working space, racks of designer clothes, and a barbershop. At the center is (h)ours, Erik Bruner-Yang’s restaurant serving peking duck with caviar, chicken wings, gnocchi alla vodka, and more. Because obviously, dinner tastes better post-haircut.

Vina Sananikone

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.sevenrooms.com/explore/menifest/reservations/create/search/)

[## Eunoia](/washington-dc/reviews/eunoia)

[320 Florida Ave NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Eunoia+320 Florida Ave NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002)

$$$$

[Fusion](/washington-dc/cuisines/fusion)

[Dupont Circle](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/dupont-circle)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Unique Dining Experiences](/washington-dc/perfect-for/unique-dining-experience)

Eunio is a Dupont Circle restaurant located in a Pilates studio in [Union Market](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-dishes-union-market). From the team behind Toolbox DC and Zeleno, the menu spans Mexico, Bulgaria, and Japan, with dishes like potato miso over seaweed mole and a striped bass quesadilla with guajillo adobo and farmhouse cheese.

Eunoia

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/eunoia-restaurant)

[## Slice & Pie](/washington-dc/reviews/slice-and-pie)

[1309 5th St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Slice%20%26%20Pie+1309 5th St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002)

$$$$

[Pizza](/washington-dc/cuisines/pizza)

[Union Market](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/union-market)

Slice & Pie's second location serves their beloved New York- and Detroit-style slices alongside an outpost of Lucy Bar at Union Market. Expect five cocktails, a short wine list, and pizza that makes mixing the two styles seem completely normal.

[## Marion Barry Avenue Market](/washington-dc/reviews/marion-barry-avenue-market)

[1303 Marion Barry Ave SE, Washington, District of Columbia 20020](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Marion%20Barry%20Avenue%20Market+1303 Marion Barry Ave SE, Washington, District of Columbia 20020)

$$$$

[Bakery/Cafe](/washington-dc/cuisines/bakerycafe)

[Anacostia](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/anacostia)

Anacostia’s Marion Barry Avenue Market is more than a grocery and café. Aiming to help end food deserts in Ward 8, the market is backed by Dreaming Out Loud and José Andrés’ Longer Tables Fund. It stocks sliding-scale produce from local growers and serves a soul food-inspired menu for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

[## Omakase Room By Tadayoshi](/washington-dc/reviews/omakase-room-by-tadayoshi)

[699 14th St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20005](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Omakase%20Room%20By%20Tadayoshi+699 14th St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20005)

$$$$

[Japanese](/washington-dc/cuisines/japanese)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

Omakase Room, a sushi restaurant with locations in New York and Chicago, has opened a new outpost Downtown. At the 12-seat omakase counter, chef Tadayoshi Motoa offers 20 courses for $200. There are two seatings per night, at 6:00 and 8:30.

Rachel Paraoan

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/restaurant/profile/1467751?ref=16825)

## September

[## Maison Bar À Vins](/washington-dc/reviews/maison-bar-a-vins)

[1834 Columbia Rd NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Maison%20Bar%20%C3%80%20Vins+1834 Columbia Rd NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009)

$$$$

[Wine Bar](/washington-dc/cuisines/wine-bar)

[Adams Morgan](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/adams-morgan)

Perfect For:[Late Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/late-nights)[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)[Drinking Great Wine](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinking-great-wine)[Drinks & A Light Bite](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinks-a-light-bite)

It takes something special to get us excited about another French wine bar, but if anything can pull us out of our neo-bistro ennui, it's a three-story spot from the team behind some of our other favorite restaurants, [Pascual](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/pascual) and [Lutèce](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/lutece). Their new spot, Maison Bar à Vins, will have a cellar stocked with over 1,000 bottles, and a kitchen pumping out dishes like eel croquettes, crudo, and a brioche-stuffed chicken. Plus, they’re open until midnight Fridays and Saturdays—a rarity in DC.

Deb Lindsey

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/maison)

[## Florería Atlántico](/washington-dc/reviews/floreria-atlantico)

[1066 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Florer%C3%ADa%20Atl%C3%A1ntico+1066 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007)

$$$$

[Bar](/washington-dc/cuisines/bar)

[Georgetown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/georgetown)

Florería Atlántico, a beloved Buenos Aires bar, has opened a DC outpost in Georgetown with a dual concept: a street-level flower shop for petunias and dahlias that hides the entrance to the speakeasy-style bar. Cocktails start flowing at 4pm, while the restaurant side, Brasero Atlántico, will debut later with wood-fired Argentine dishes.

Florería Atlántico

[## Dawa at Elmina](/washington-dc/reviews/dawa-at-elmina)

[2208 14th St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Dawa%20at%20Elmina%20+2208 14th St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009)

$$$$

[Ghanaian](/washington-dc/cuisines/ghanaian)

[U Street](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/u-street)

Dawa is a new carryout and delivery concept from Eric Adjepong, run out of the kitchen at [Elmina](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/elmina). Open Monday through Saturday for lunch and dinner, the menu includes pepper soup consommé ramen (interesting), tamarind duck leg (very interesting), and oxtail stew (yes). Available for pickup or through third-party apps.

[## Desert 5 Spot](/washington-dc/reviews/desert-5-spot-dc)

[400 Morse St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Desert%205%20Spot+400 Morse St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002)

$$$$

[Bar](/washington-dc/cuisines/bar)

[Union Market](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/union-market)

We love a theme, and LA’s country-western bar Desert 5 has brought one to the former Palette 22 space. The two-story spot has a rooftop cactus garden, a DJ booth made from a vintage Chevy truck, and daily live sets from country artists. The menu leans Southern with Nashville chicken sliders and spare ribs.

Cesar Soto

[## Acqua Bistecca](/washington-dc/reviews/acqua-bistecca)

[14 Ridge Square NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20016](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Acqua%20Bistecca+14 Ridge Square NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20016)

$$$$

[Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/italian)

[Tenleytown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/tenleytown)

Chef Michael Mina of [Bourbon Steak](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/bourbon-steak-dc), a go-to for DC power lunches, has opened Acqua Bistecca in National Landing. The Italian restaurant focuses on shareable plates, housemade pastas, fresh seafood, and chargrilled steaks.

Rey Lopez

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/restaurant/profile/1464676?ref=16825)

[## Hush Harbor DC](/washington-dc/reviews/hush-harbor-dc)

[1337 H St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Hush%20Harbor%20DC+1337 H St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002)

$$$$

[Bar](/washington-dc/cuisines/bar)

[H Street](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/h-street)

No phones are allowed at Hush Harbor DC, the city’s first bar with a strict unplugged policy. Instead, you’ll find Polaroid film, shrimp remoulade, Cajun red beans and rice, a lending library, and trivia nights. It's like a subtle intervention for the friend glued to Slack.

Rey Lopez

[## Chai Pani](/washington-dc/reviews/chai-pani-dc)

[1325 5th St NE, Washington, DC 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Chai%20Pani+1325 5th St NE, Washington, DC 20002)

$$$$

[Indian](/washington-dc/cuisines/indian)

[Union Market](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/union-market)

Perfect For:[Big Groups](/washington-dc/perfect-for/big-groups)[Lunch](/washington-dc/perfect-for/lunch)[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)

Another month, another Union Market spot for the list. Chai Pani brings Indian street food with okra fries, tamarind-glazed ribs, and a Kashmiri take on a fried chicken sandwich with mint, chili, Maggi-mayo, and pickles.

Jonathan Smith

8.7

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/chai-pani-washington-dc?ref=16825)

[## Sports & Social](/washington-dc/reviews/sports-and-social)

[1314 U St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Sports%20%26%20Social+1314 U St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009)

$$$$

[Bar](/washington-dc/cuisines/bar)

[U Street](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/u-street)

Sports & Social on U Street has a 25-foot LED wall and more than a dozen TVs. The menu, from the team behind [Chiko](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/chiko) and [Anju](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/anju), features hot Maryland crab dip, wings, and pit beef on weck (a Buffalo-style roast beef sandwich on a salted roll, made here with 2Fifty smoked beef).

Sports & Social

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/sports-and-social-dc-washington?ref=16825)

[## Flor. Coffee + Books](/washington-dc/reviews/flor-coffee-books)

[1220 31st St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Flor.%20Coffee%20%2B%20Books+1220 31st St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007)

$$$$

[Bakery/Cafe](/washington-dc/cuisines/bakery-cafe)

[Georgetown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/georgetown)

Flor. Coffee + Books in Georgetown is part café, part bookshop serving Grace Street coffee, empanadas, Argentine and French pastries, and Dolcezza soft serve.

Mateo Cocito

[## ZomTum](/washington-dc/reviews/zomtum)

[660 Pennsylvania Ave SE, Washington, District of Columbia 20003](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=ZomTum+660 Pennsylvania Ave SE, Washington, District of Columbia 20003)

$$$$

[Thai](/washington-dc/cuisines/thai)

[Capitol Hill](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/capitol-hill)

Across from Eastern Market Metro on Capitol Hill, ZomTum is serving Lao and Thai dishes like papaya salad, curries, noodles, and wontons. It is, according to their tagline, “where papaya meets paradise.”

ZomTum

## August

[## Daily Provisions](/washington-dc/reviews/daily-provisions-dc)

[1601 Connecticut Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Daily%20Provisions+1601 Connecticut Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009)

$$$$

[Coffee](/washington-dc/cuisines/coffee)

[Dupont Circle](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/dupont-circle)

New York-based Daily Provisions is now open in Dupont. The all-day counter-service spot from Danny Meyer serves sandwiches, salads, and baked goods alongside wine, beer, and cocktails. They've also got a half-smoke egg & cheese for the DC location, which we're not *not* interested in...

Daily Provisions

[## Bibibop](/washington-dc/reviews/bibibop)

[1516 Connecticut Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20036](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Bibibop+1516 Connecticut Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20036)

$$$$

[Korean](/washington-dc/cuisines/korean)

[Georgetown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/georgetown)

Bibibop, the Korean-inspired fast casual chain, is now in Georgetown with build-your-own bowls of sweet potato noodles, steak, miso-glazed salmon, purple rice, and sauces from yum yum to gochujang.

[## Nuli](/washington-dc/reviews/nuli)

[1850 K St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20006](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Nuli+1850 K St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20006)

$$$$

[Nigerian](/washington-dc/cuisines/nigerian)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

The latest addition to DC's seemingly unstoppable fast-casual lunch bowl scene is Nuli, a Nigerian chain with a focus on healthy ingredients. Located Downtown at the Square food hall, Nuli serves proteins like lamb meatballs and spicy prawns over bases like couscous, fonio, and rice.

Scott Suchman

[## Wings On Deck](/washington-dc/reviews/wings-on-deck)

[6912 Fourth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20012](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Wings%20On%20Deck+6912 Fourth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20012)

$$$$

[Fast Food](/washington-dc/cuisines/fast-food)

[Takoma Park](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/takoma-park)

Wings On Deck, a longtime DC favorite, has moved from Georgia Avenue to Takoma. Wings are available in flavors like parmesan garlic, lemon pepper, cajun honey, and more. For those looking for non-chicken dishes, they've got sides like collards and onion rings, and a range of fried fish.

[## Taco Cat](/washington-dc/reviews/taco-cat)

[2000 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20052](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Taco%20Cat+2000 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20052)

$$$$

[Mexican](/washington-dc/cuisines/mexican)

[Foggy Bottom](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/foggy-bottom)

Tim Ma doesn't sleep. After opening [Kata](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/kata), [Lucky Danger](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/lucky-danger), and [Sushi Sato](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/sushi-sato-dc) earlier this year, he's got another new spot inside Western Market. Taco Cat is slinging breakfast tacos as well as an all-day lineup of burritos, ceviche, and one very compelling tuna taco in a crispy nori shell. Open Monday through Friday 8am-8pm, they've also got a tequila and mezcal-heavy cocktail menu.

Rachel Paraoan

## July

[## Street Burger](/washington-dc/reviews/street-burger)

[507 Seventh St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20004](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Street%20Burger+507 Seventh St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20004)

$$$$

[Burgers](/washington-dc/cuisines/burgers)

[Penn Quarter](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/penn-quarter)

Gordon Ramsay’s U.K.-based Street Burger has made the leap across the pond. Its first U.S. location is now open in Penn Quarter, serving smash burgers like the Hell’s Kitchen, stacked with jalapeños, spicy chutney, and crispy onions.

Street Burger

[RESERVE A TABLE](http://www.opentable.com/r/gordon-ramsay-street-burger-washington-dc-washington?ref=16825)

[## Fancy Ranch Amish Fried Chicken](/washington-dc/reviews/fancy-ranch-amish-fried-chicken)

# The Hit List: New DC Restaurants To Try Right Now

Your guide to the best new restaurants in Chocolate City.

photo credit: Eunoia

[Madeline Weinfield](/contributor/madeline-weinfield), [Jonathan Smith](/contributor/jonathan-smith), [Allison Robicelli](/contributor/allison-robicelli) & [Thomas Rose](/contributor/tom-rose)

When new restaurants open, we check them out. This means that we subject our stomachs and social lives to the good, the bad, and more often than not, the perfectly fine. And every once in a while, a new spot makes us feel like Kamala Harris at a pantsuit sale. When that happens, we add it here, to The Hit List.

The Hit List is where you’ll find all of the best new restaurants in DC**.** As long as it opened within the past several months and we’re still talking about it, it’s on this guide.The latest addition might be a buzzy new restaurant with caviar priced by the bump. Or it might be an under-the-radar lunch counter where a few dollars will get something that’ll rattle around in your brain like a loose penny in a dryer.

Keep tabs on the Hit List and you will always know just which new restaurants you should be eating at right now.

**New to the Hit List (12/11): Eunoia**

###### What Our Ratings Mean

[Learn more](/ratings-explainer)

NONE

1-5

6s

7s

8s

9s

Unrated: This is a restaurant we want to re-visit before rating, or it’s a coffee shop, bar, or dessert shop. We only rate spots where you can eat a full meal.

## THE SPOTS

[## Eunoia](/washington-dc/reviews/eunoia)

[320 Florida Ave NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Eunoia+320 Florida Ave NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002)

$$$$

[Fusion](/washington-dc/cuisines/fusion)

[Dupont Circle](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/dupont-circle)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Unique Dining Experiences](/washington-dc/perfect-for/unique-dining-experience)

At first glance, nothing about Eunoia makes a lot of sense. The menu, which leans heavily into Mexican cuisine (tacos and mole are stars), steers without warning into Bulgarian and Japanese flavors, with some phyllo dough here and some miso paste there. The upscale [Union Market](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-dishes-union-market) space seems to be more straightforward, playing into the industrial-chic nature of the building, with high ceilings, glass walls, and exposed pipes. But then, as if taking a cue from the menu, the unexpected comes into view: Eunoia isn’t just a restaurant, it’s also a Pilates studio. It is, admittedly, a bit weird. But the food—the improbable mashup of three unrelated cuisines—lands. So much so that we’re willing to look past the bare feet crossing our sightline mid-bite.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/eunoia-restaurant)

Eunoia

[## Eebee’s Corner Bar](/washington-dc/reviews/eebees-corner-bar)

[1840 Sixth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Eebee%E2%80%99s%20Corner%20Bar+1840 Sixth St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20001)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Shaw](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/shaw)

Perfect For:[Drinking Great Cocktails](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinking-great-cocktails)[Night On The Town](/washington-dc/perfect-for/night-on-the-town)[Late Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/late-nights)[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)

The debut venture from the beer director behind [Green Zone](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/the-green-zone) and the ever-expanding Andy’s Pizza empire, Eebee’s caters to off-shift industry workers with a kitchen that’s open until 2am. It's a bar first and foremost, but the food is no afterthought. Options include a turkey club, shrimp cocktail, and some of the best mozzarella sticks we’ve ever had, thinly breaded with almost no grease. There’s also a $25 burger with a perfectly seasoned, nearly two-inch-thick patty. The place hits capacity early and stays that way through most weekend nights, but even on school nights most bar seats are filled by off-shift hospitality workers. Order a martini and the onion rings or club sandwich and strike up a conversation with a stranger. If they end up becoming your emergency contact, nobody will be surprised—this place was designed for a meet-cute.

Thomas Rose

[## Maison Bar À Vins](/washington-dc/reviews/maison-bar-a-vins)

[1834 Columbia Rd NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Maison%20Bar%20%C3%80%20Vins+1834 Columbia Rd NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009)

$$$$

[Wine Bar](/washington-dc/cuisines/wine-bar)

[Adams Morgan](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/adams-morgan)

Perfect For:[Late Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/late-nights)[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)[Drinking Great Wine](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinking-great-wine)[Drinks & A Light Bite](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinks-a-light-bite)

The latest jewel box of a restaurant from the team behind [Lutéce](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/lutece) and [Pascual](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/pascual)—people who seem constitutionally incapable of getting it wrong—sits in a former [Adams Morgan](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-restaurants-bars-adams-morgan-dc) row home that spent three decades as the Cuban nightclub Habana Village. Anyone who appreciates Lutèce and Pascal’s penchant for biodynamic wines will find plenty to love here, with a list that runs over a thousand vintages long. But while Maison Bar à Vins bills itself as a wine bar, the food alone is worth a visit. The smoked eel croquettes, exceptionally creamy and topped with a thin sliver of singed eel, are a standout. For something more substantial, the brioche stuffed chicken is theoretically big enough to share, but the crunchy brioche and buttery chanterelle mushrooms could turn the most communal-minded diner into a food hoarder.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/maison)

Deb Lindsey

[## (H)ours At Manifest 002](/washington-dc/reviews/manifest-002)

[1242 Third St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=(H)ours%20At%20Manifest%20002+1242 Third St NE, Washington, District of Columbia 20002)

$$$$

[Fusion](/washington-dc/cuisines/fusion)

[Union Market](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/union-market)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)[First Dates](/washington-dc/perfect-for/first-dates)[See & Be Seen](/washington-dc/perfect-for/see-and-be-seen)[Drinking Great Cocktails](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinking-great-cocktails)

(H)ours At Manifest 002 bucks DC stereotypes. Instead of cold concrete and brutalist angles, its lilac cushions and soft edges. Instead of imported politicians in poorly tailored suits, it’s homegrown hustlers in Margiela jackets. And instead of traditional steakhouse fare, it’s contemporary soul food fused with flavors from around the world. The restaurant is attached to a members club that also includes a barber shop, cafe, retail store, and more. Just like the building it’s in, the food here isn’t content to be simply one thing. Butter for the bread is also a lit candle. Signature cocktails include an aromatic bowl of tea. And the dishes pair flavors from opposite sides of the globe. At (H)ours, tuna crudo meets chow-chow and bolognese shakes hands with Ethiopian spice.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.sevenrooms.com/explore/menifest/reservations/create/search/)

Vina Sananikone

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Drinking Great Cocktails](/washington-dc/perfect-for/drinking-great-cocktails)[Night On The Town](/washington-dc/perfect-for/night-on-the-town)[Special Occasions](/washington-dc/perfect-for/special-occasions)

Karravaan in [Union Market](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-dishes-union-market) feels like it’s been here for a hundred years. The restaurant channels the sleek glamor of a 1920s Beirut café crossed with a waiting room for the Orient Express, with tiled floors, bentwood chairs, an oversized clock, and a wall of windows that seems perfect for watching an approaching train. That mishmash of design choices makes sense in a restaurant whose menu traces the Silk Road, serving up dishes like falafel topped with slivered ginger, khachapuri filled with steaming goat feta, and lamb sliders with sumac and jalapenos. Za’atar fries are a natural companion, as are the cocktails, like the mezcal and pét-nat Bedouin Sunset, which is mixed with lime bitters and blood orange syrup.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/karravaan)

Birch Thomas

[## Sushi Gaku](/washington-dc/reviews/sushi-gaku)

[1338 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Sushi%20Gaku+1338 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007)

A downtown DC favorite until it closed in late 2024, Sushi Gaku has resurfaced in [Georgetown](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/georgetown-restaurants) with a new address and a new look. Yes, you can still splurge on the $180 omakase, but the à la carte menu makes it just as easy to have a good time. The lightly spicy tuna roll has just enough crunch, while the eel nigiri is good enough to tempt an all-eel order (a true chaos move, but do you). Set in a quiet basement with a dining room that opens onto a courtyard filled with bistro tables, the vibe at Sushi Gaku exists somewhere between private club and cozy hangout, and is as suited to last-minute business dinners on the corporate card as it is a low-key date night.

[## Cafe Fiorello](/washington-dc/reviews/cafe-fiorello-dc)

[1001 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20004](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Cafe%20Fiorello+1001 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20004)

[Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/italian)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)

The first thing you should do at Café Fiorello is order a martini. Not only will it be perfectly chilled and shaken with just enough olive brine to keep things interesting, but it will arrive at your table on a silver tray and delicately placed on the white tablecloth by a server who seems like they’ve been training their whole life for this moment. The Italian American restaurant has been a [New York City institution](https://www.theinfatuation.com/new-york/reviews/cafe-fiorello) since 1974, and the DC outpost has captured the spirit of the original. It’s easy to get swept up in the beauty of Fiorello’s pastas (their peppery spaghetti carbonara is shockingly rich, and exactly what we crave on a cold evening). But the eggplant parmesan is the star of the menu. Their version takes up an entire dinner plate, and while this is a dish that usually makes us want to go take a nap, Fiorello’s version is lighter thanks to the fact that the eggplant is baked rather than breaded and fried.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/cafe-fiorello-dc-washington?ref=16825)

[## My Little Chamomile](/washington-dc/reviews/my-little-chamomile)

[3210 Cherry Hill Ln NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=My%20Little%20Chamomile%20+3210 Cherry Hill Ln NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20007)

$$$$

[Turkish](/washington-dc/cuisines/turkish)

[Georgetown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/georgetown)

Perfect For:[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)

My Little Chamomile is a Turkish restaurant from the team behind [Green Almond Pantry](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/green-almond-pantry). Tucked down a quaint [Georgetown](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/georgetown-restaurants) alley, the quiet dining room is a place you can bring your parents, your professor, or anyone you need to whisper a secret to without having to shout across the table. The vegetable-forward menu works best shared, and the smallish portions make it easy to skip around. If tomatoes are still in season, start with the super fresh coban salatası. Otherwise, the girit ezmesi, an overload of feta, labneh, and goat cheese whipped together and dusted with pistachios, or the dedemin biberi, anaheim peppers marinated in vinegar and garlic with just enough kick to make them interesting, both make great ice breakers. For something more substantial, we love the mantı beef dumplings with yogurt. Finish with chamomile tea (naturally) and the tel kadayıf, a dessert that recalls baklava but uses shredded phyllo.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/my-little-chamomile-washington-dc?ref=16825)

[## Fish Shop](/washington-dc/reviews/fish-shop-dc)

[610 Water St SW, Washington DC, District of Columbia 20024](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Fish%20Shop+610 Water St SW, Washington DC, District of Columbia 20024)

[Wharf](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/wharf)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)

We’re a little confused as to why the second location of Fish Shop opened in DC (the original is in the Scottish countryside town of Ballater, pop. 1400) but we’re not complaining. Opened by the folks at Artfarm, the hospitality arm of the global gallery Hauser & Wirth, the sweeping 180-seat seafood spot takes some inspiration from the gallery, with a massive installation of floating fish sculpted from North Carolina wisteria and Scottish willow. While Fish Shop's roots are Scottish, its menu is decidedly mid-Atlantic, built around what’s fresh from the Chesapeake Bay, Rappahannock River, Atlantic Ocean, and local farms. Think small bites like Maryland crab crumpets and New Jersey squid, as well as hearty mains like Maryland blue crab conchiglie and grilled New Jersey mackerel. For desert, try the tiramisu made with candied Virginia peanuts.

Dave Watts

[## Chai Pani](/washington-dc/reviews/chai-pani-dc)

[1325 5th St NE, Washington, DC 20002](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Chai%20Pani+1325 5th St NE, Washington, DC 20002)

$$$$

[Indian](/washington-dc/cuisines/indian)

[Union Market](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/union-market)

Perfect For:[Big Groups](/washington-dc/perfect-for/big-groups)[Lunch](/washington-dc/perfect-for/lunch)[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)

There is nothing subtle about Chai Pani in Union Market. The 4,000 square-foot space sits under a canopy of bright pink bougainvilleas and orange garlands, and a mini market complete with a photogenic pani puri cart sells spices, cookbooks, and other branded merch. But underneath the splashy space, Chai Pani is serving some of the best [Indian food](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-indian-restaurants-dc) in DC. You can go alone, but we wouldn’t recommend it. Come with a crew and order a spread of chaat like the excellent kale pakora, with a batter so light and crispy you’ll swear they found a way to deep-fry air, or the puri with potato, onion, and sweet yogurt. The Sloppy Jai, made with spiced lamb, green chutney, and sweet yogurt, is a staple of the restaurant's original location in [Asheville](https://www.theinfatuation.com/asheville/reviews/chai-pani-asheville), and it’s served here as two small pav sliders, ideal for sharing. Chai Pani knows how to play the hits, too. The methi malai paneer is rich with cashew cream and cardamom, and a nice anchor for a lot of the small plates that should be flying around your table.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://www.opentable.com/r/chai-pani-washington-dc?ref=16825)

Jonathan Smith

[## Elmina](/washington-dc/reviews/elmina)

[2208 14th St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Elmina+2208 14th St NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20009)

$$$$

[Ghanaian](/washington-dc/cuisines/ghanaian)

[U Street](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/u-street)

Perfect For:[Date Nights](/washington-dc/perfect-for/date-night)[Dinner with the Parents](/washington-dc/perfect-for/dinner-with-the-parents)[Impressing Out of Towners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/impressing-out-of-towners)[Special Occasions](/washington-dc/perfect-for/special-occasions)

Elmina is what happens when Ghanaian food shows up to DC’s fine dining scene in its Sunday best. The $135 four-course tasting menu blends deep tradition with sharp technique: think scallop crudo with citrus and coconut, rich palm nut stew with shrimp and octopus, and a jollof duck pot dripping with smoky, pepper-laced shito. The obvious move at Elmina, from celebrity chef Eric Adjepong, is to come for a birthday, anniversary, or some other occasion that warrants a nice shirt and planning ahead. And while it’s great for that, we also love to come here on a whim and sit at the bar for the more casual a la carte menu, where you can get bites like okra fries, octopus kebabs with a shito glaze, or a hamachi collar with plantain chips.

[## Osteria Mozza](/washington-dc/reviews/osteria-mozza-dc)

[3276 M St NW, Washington DC, 20007](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Osteria%20Mozza+3276 M St NW, Washington DC, 20007)

$$$$

[Italian](/washington-dc/cuisines/italian)

[Georgetown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/georgetown)

Eighteen years after Nancy Silverton opened [Osteria Mozza](https://www.theinfatuation.com/los-angeles/reviews/osteria-mozza) in LA, the iconic Italian restaurant has arrived in [Georgetown](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/georgetown-restaurants). It doesn’t matter why or when you find yourself underneath the dining room’s soaring ceilings, eating at Osteria Mozza feels like an occasion. Start with the Focaccia di Recco. It’s not an option so much as a necessity—an ultra-thin, crispy, cheese-stuffed marvel finished with some of the best olive oil we’ve ever tasted. The sea trout is pan-seared to crisp-skinned perfection, its buttery flesh offset by the acidity of braised red cabbage, earthy Roveja peas, and the surprising richness of hard-boiled eggs. But if we had to pick just one reason to visit Osteria Mozza, it would be the dessert menu. The tiramisu is outstanding, but playing favorites feels unfair. If you decided to skip dinner entirely and focus solely on desserts, we wouldn’t judge you. In fact, we might join you.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://osteriamozzadc.com/menus/dinner/#)

Nina Palazzolo

[## The Occidental](/washington-dc/reviews/the-occidental)

[1475 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20004](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=The%20Occidental+1475 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20004)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

Originally opened in 1906 a stone’s throw from the White House, generations of presidents, senators, and journalists have flocked to The Occidental to make history, or drink their way out of it. Now, after a century of grandeur interspersed with bouts of irrelevance, Stephen Starr has stepped in and dusted off the red velvet. The midcentury menu revives dishes that haven’t been on-trend since the Eisenhower administration, and does them so spectacularly you’ll wonder how exactly they went out of style in the first place. You’ll find the requisite raw bar with oysters and cold king crab legs, but also a nod to Soviet dining in the herring under a fur coat. There’s caviar and crab cakes, of course, but also pigs in a blanket, made from Hebrew National hot dogs wrapped in the Occidental’s soon-to-be-legendary biscuits. The Occidental is a loving homage—and an assertive return—to power dining with a wink and a flourish, where you can eat like a Kennedy and drink like a Cold War diplomat.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/the-occidental)

Birch Thomas

# Where To Eat When You’re Visiting DC

A spot for every meal—and then some.

photo credit: Birch Thomas

[Tristiaña Hinton](/contributor/tristiana-hinton), [Allison Robicelli](/contributor/allison-robicelli), [Jonathan Smith](/contributor/jonathan-smith) & [Thomas Rose](/contributor/tom-rose)

Welcome to our nation’s capital, a city of big monuments and even bigger culture. And our food scene is laced with every bit of that culture, whether it’s from down the block or halfway across the world. With so many choices, it can be overwhelming to decide where to eat after a day of exploring our [free museums](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/smithsonian-restaurants-dc-ranked) (seriously, y’all pay for that in your city?). Here are a few great places to check out when you’re in DC, even if you’re only here for a day.

###### What Our Ratings Mean

[Learn more](/ratings-explainer)

Unrated: This is a restaurant we want to re-visit before rating, or it’s a coffee shop, bar, or dessert shop. We only rate spots where you can eat a full meal.

## BREAKFAST

[## Any Day Now](/washington-dc/reviews/any-day-now-dc)

[2 I St SE, Washington, D.C. 20003](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Any%20Day%20Now+2 I St SE, Washington, D.C. 20003)

$$$$

[Navy Yard](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/navy-yard)

Perfect For:[Getting Work Done](/washington-dc/perfect-for/getting-work-done)[Breakfast](/washington-dc/perfect-for/breakfast)[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)

There are a few reasons to hit this all-day American restaurant and cafe in [Navy Yard](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/nats-park-navy-yard-restaurants-bars), like their homemade cold brew and buttery croissants. But it’s the scallion-pancake egg sandwich that will turn anyone (including tourists here for more than a day) into a regular. It comes with your choice of bacon, kimchi, or sausage, and is served with a spicy, tangy garlic-chili oil. It's a great spot to work while you eat if you’re in town on business, but is also a good choice for a family meal. Lounge on a green tweed couch if you're looking to kick back, or grab a more sturdy (but still comfortable) booth if you're there to grind.

[RESERVE A TABLE](http://www.opentable.com/r/any-day-now-washington?ref=16825)

Nina Palazzolo

Perfect For:[Casual Dinners](/washington-dc/perfect-for/casual-dinners)[Breakfast](/washington-dc/perfect-for/breakfast)[Brunch](/washington-dc/perfect-for/brunch)[Big Groups](/washington-dc/perfect-for/big-groups)[Sitting Outside](/washington-dc/perfect-for/sitting-outside)

It’s easy to miss Kafe Leopold, tucked down Cady’s Alley in Georgetown behind a barrage of interior design stores. In fact, you might mistake the Austrian restaurant for an outpost of Design Within Reach, with its sprawling dining room anchored in the middle by a bright orange Tatlin sofa. This is a utilitarian spot that’s better than it needs to be, and the lengthy menu at the all-day cafe has options for whenever you might stop by. They're open from 8am until 10pm (and 11pm on Fridays and Saturdays), but we like it best for breakfast or brunch with a group where everyone can spread out in the sunny dining room. Try the salmon pizzette, served with horseradish creme and crispy radishes, or mix and match a trio of tea sandwiches with options like tomato and mozzarella, egg salad, and apple and cheese on a pretzel bun.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/kafe-leopold)

The oldest [Black-owned](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/black-owned-restaurants-washington-dc) American restaurant in the city requires some planning if you want to taste their famous hot cakes, served with butter, cinnamon, and powdered sugar. After more than 70 years in business, the Shaw spot only opens Friday through Sunday from 9am-2pm. That makes it perfect if you’re in town for the weekend, but block out a couple hours for your meal because things take time here. But as they say, good things come to those who wait, and the wait for dishes like the cajun fried catfish that have been perfected over the decades, is most definitely worth it..

This former Navy Yard café was once next to its sister restaurant, [Albi](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/reviews/albi), but has since found new life in both Georgetown and Union Market. We’re partial to the Georgetown location for its shopping proximity, and the plush couches provide the perfect spot to people-watch or read the paperback you just picked up at Politics and Prose. Both cafés have solid breakfast options that tend to sell out quickly, so the sooner you can scoot on in, the better. Our latest obsessions are the cardamom chocolate cruffin—that’s a combo we didn’t know we needed—and the super-stuffed BBQ cauliflower pita that’s so huge, you could probably save half of it for a snack later.

Rey Lopez

Comme des Garçons Converse collabs, the third Tame Impala record, an issue of *Kinfolk*... At one point, you could purchase all these things at Maketto while eating a steamed bao. Today, it’s shed most of its past as the first boutique clothing store/bistro mashup in DC. And that’s a good thing, because what Maketto does best is serve excellent Taiwanese and Cambodian food. The lengthy menu features soft ball-sized pork baos, various dumplings, noodles, and Maketto’s specialty, twice-fried chicken. It's open for dinner but is especially great during the daytime, when moms with strollers take away pandan lattes while 30-somethings in big coats and tiny beanies ride laptops and slurp lo mein.

Melanie Landsman

[## Sweet Home Café](/washington-dc/reviews/sweet-home-cafe)

[1400 Constitution Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20560](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=Sweet%20Home%20Caf%C3%A9+1400 Constitution Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20560)

$$$$

[Soul Food](/washington-dc/cuisines/soul-food)

[Penn Quarter](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/penn-quarter)

Perfect For:[Lunch](/washington-dc/perfect-for/lunch)[Walk-Ins](/washington-dc/perfect-for/walk-ins)

The restaurant at the National African American Museum is so good it inspired its own [cookbook](https://nmaahc.si.edu/explore/publications/sweet-home-cafe-cookbook). Taking cues from four regions telling vastly different stories about the African American experience, Sweet Home Café's menu changes frequently, but if the deservedly popular fried chicken is available, order it. With a crunchy seasoned breading that puts the Colonel’s to shame, the meat is as succulent as a well-brined bird can be.For sides, the mac and cheese tastes like a recipe that’s been proudly passed down through generations, and the humble potato salad, typically the least glamorous dish on any menu, is spectacular. Skip the banana pudding, which tastes heavily artificial, and go straight for the sweet potato pie, barely sweetened with just the right amount of spice.

Josh Weilepp/NMAAHC

## DINNER

[## The Occidental](/washington-dc/reviews/the-occidental)

[1475 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20004](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=The%20Occidental+1475 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, District of Columbia 20004)

$$$$

[American](/washington-dc/cuisines/american)

[Downtown](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/downtown)

Originally opened in 1906, generations of presidents, senators, and journalists have flocked to The Occidental to make history, or drink their way out of it. The end of the Cuban Missile Crisis was sparked here after a plate of pork chops, and the latest iteration of the restaurant, from Stephen Starr, is as suited to solving geopolitical crises as it is celebrating an anniversary or a promotion. The midcentury menu revives dishes that haven’t been on-trend since the Eisenhower administration, and does them so spectacularly you’ll wonder how exactly they went out of style in the first place. You’ll find the requisite raw bar with oysters and cold king crab legs, but also a nod to Soviet dining in the herring under a fur coat.

[RESERVE A TABLE](https://resy.com/cities/washington-dc/venues/the-occidental)

Birch Thomas

To get an understanding of just how good the food in DC truly is, go to Thip Khao. The Lao restaurant in [Columbia Heights](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/where-to-eat-and-drink-in-columbia-heights) always has a line by the time they open, with crowds waiting to order dishes like the mee kathi, a noodle soup we can’t stop dreaming about. [1100 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20004](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=The%20Bazaar+1100 Pennsylvania Ave NW, Washington, D.C. 20004)

[Spanish](/washington-dc/cuisines/spanish)

[Penn Quarter](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/penn-quarter)

Perfect For:[Birthdays](/washington-dc/perfect-for/birthdays)[Corporate Cards](/washington-dc/perfect-for/corporate-cards)

José Andrés' DC empire continues with The Bazaar, a Spanish restaurant located in the Waldorf Hotel at the Old Post Office with lush cathedral arches and grand crystal chandeliers. There are cherry blossom trees in full bloom, indoors. It’s dramatic and fantastical—which is exactly the vibe at The Bazaar, where drinks are displayed in clouds of dry ice to guests wearing dark wash jeans and $30,000 watches. On the menu are quirky and creative tapas like cotton candy foie gras. But, as is the flaw with some of Andrés’ restaurants, the menu is inconsistent. Some entrees are excellent, like the philly cheesesteak, a deconstructed take on an old-school classic, and some fall flat, like the dragon fruit ceviche served with a peach-ring fruity foam that just does not work.

This Capitol Hill institution is a great place to grab a drink and imagine all the secrets these walls have heard. It looks like an old lodge, full of pictures of ancient men you’ll definitely recognize from their days at 1600 Pennsylvania. There are, of course, Hill staffers and lobbyists hanging around and acting important, but you’ll also find locals swinging by. If you’re lucky enough to come through with an old head, they’re likely to have a Hawk ‘n’ Dove story that will make you understand how rooted the restaurant is, not just on the Hill, but to the people who make up the fabric of DC.

Hawk 'n' Dove

This [Georgetown](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/georgetown-restaurants) lounge is an excellent way to wrap a long day of shopping and meandering along the C&O Canal. The inventive cocktail menu includes drinks like the Bay of Bengal, served in a flowered tea cup, or the Sakura, which tastes like a vesper martini served in a sake glass. It’s open until 1am during the week and 2am on the weekends, and feels like a place where you’ll meet a mysterious stranger who is an international spy. [2226 18th St NW, Washington, DC 20009](https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=The%20Green%20Zone+2226 18th St NW, Washington, DC 20009)

The Green Zone is one of the [best bars](https://www.theinfatuation.com/washington-dc/guides/best-bars-dc) in DC, so it gets packed early. Head over around 4pm so you can grab a seat before the crowd arrives. Named after an area in Baghdad, this Middle Eastern bar serves a bunch of craft cocktails featuring ingredients from that part of the world, like the Women. Life. Freedom, a vodka-based drink with cardamom and rose. The bar does have strong political stances—one of the drinks is called the F\*ck Trump punch—so do with that what you will.

[Logan Circle](/washington-dc/neighborhoods/logan-circle)

Medina might be the only bar in DC that we dream about, thanks to their indoor bedouin tent and cocktails so pretty we almost don’t want to drink them. You’ll want to plan ahead for this one, because the best seats in the house are on cushy couches and those require reservations at least a couple weeks out. Once you’ve secured your spot, try the Medusa, made with mezcal and topped with a salty foam, and order some  chermoula, kefta hummus full of tiny meatballs, and endless pita bread to go with it.

### How to get into Medina

Reservations open 21 days in advance at 10am, but the majority of seating at Medina is held for walk-ins. Reserve a table to bypass the wait, but there's still a chance to spontaneously swing by without fearing your night will be cut short.

# Thomas Rose

Thomas Rose's first job was making sandwiches at a deli outside Boston where he used his paycheck to buy skateboards and t-shirts from local emo bands. He moved to DC in 2022 for a brief stint in advertising and stuck around because the city has more to offer than monuments and Hill staffers, including some incredible food. Thomas was also a co-founder and the deputy editor of indie food magazine Salt & Wonder.
